title: 104_hr851
content:
The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes a project. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to investigate the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas. The network includes physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers in a rural area collaborating with a multispecialty tertiary care provider for patient referral, joint communications, and transportation services. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas, which may include health professional shortage areas or underserved rural areas specified by the Secretary. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas, which may include health professional shortage areas or underserved rural areas specified by the Secretary. Medicare payment for participants. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes pilot projects for rural health care provider telemedicine networks in designated rural areas. The Secretary shall make payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physicians' services in rural areas, regardless of location. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payments under the Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995, including payment for nonphysician providers. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY OF NETWORKS. Networks eligible for the pilot project must submit an application with required information and agree to provide necessary data to the Secretary. The term "rural area" is defined in the Act. In the pilot project, networks must apply and provide data to the Secretary. The term "rural area" is defined in the Act as per section 1886(d)(2)(D) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS.

Priority given to networks facilitating patient-specialist consultations with detailed data transmission. Existing networks can participate.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for pilot project services, detailing participating projects and networks, expenses, and patient numbers. A final report is due within 1 year after project termination, analyzing cost-effectiveness and provider access promotion. The Secretary must submit reports to Congress on the effectiveness of pilot projects in promoting provider access to specialist consultations in rural areas, impact on patient care quality, and recommendations for changes in Medicare telemedicine programs. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 allocated for administrative purposes.
